segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 So, today I'm going to be chatting to you guys about unified Red Team automation, so
not so much automating the actual job, because as far as I'm concerned, that's still always
going to be done by people, but we're going to be mainly looking at the infrastructure
side of things and trying to kind of utilize and collate as much information into a single
portal as we can.
So, yeah, I'm going to kind of walk you through it.
The second half of the talk is all demo and live demo, so wish me luck, but we'll see
how we get on.
So, who am I?
I'm Don Morton.
I'm a Red Team specialist at Bulletproof.
I've been Red Teaming and pen testing now for probably the last nearly five years, but
the last kind of three years of that pretty much solid in Red Teaming.
Before that, I was a sysadmin, so automating things and basically taking the laziest way
out of stuff is pretty much how I learn IT.
You've probably seen me around Discord as either like Czar, I think I'm on Twitter at
DSEC or some variation of it, so, yeah, feel free to grab me for a chat.
So we're just going to have a quick look at kind of what this is, what I'm going to be
talking about, and the portal I've designed to do it.
What I viewed as the current challenges and what was annoying me or frustrating me in
terms of deploying infrastructure in a quick way, getting information from it and sharing
it between multiple resources, and then we'll look at the general approach I kind of took,
so with a big caveat of I'm not a dev in any way, shape, or form, so I've probably done
some really stupid design choices, but it works.
So we'll then pick up with a kind of demo, and I'll run through building some infrastructure,
show what it looks like, and then show the additional features of bringing information
together within kind of a single portal that I've done, and then I'll discuss the kind
of future plans and releases and things that are coming, stuff that you guys can actually
get involved with.
So yeah, as I mentioned, it's a look into the approaches used to simplify and centralize
the deployment and management of infrastructure, and now probably considerably more, starting
to add in sort of more and more features, and this is achieved using a web-based tool
that I've called Red Commander.
So it's all based on open source kind of, well, Django platform, and we'll have a kind
of sneak peek into all of that.
So the current challenges I kind of identified and things I didn't like with how I was deploying
infrastructure currently was that there's tons of open source, multiple open source
sort of CICD and CLI-based Terraform Ansible deployment tools, and they all require lots
of heavy customization, you're constantly adding the same IPs, you're having one operator
deploying resources completely independently from everyone else, you have no visibility
across your different resources, and some of these are quite out of date or they're
really overly complex and use new Ansible roles, new functionality that is quickly depreciated
or moved on and APIs changed, so you're constantly having to repair things.
So I was like, right, I'm going to try and keep it as simple as possible, take out all
the room for errors, and design something suitable.
As I mentioned, managing and deploying infrastructure across multiple cloud providers and systems
is also a bit of a pain.
These days we kind of utilize any cloud system or cloud platform we can, be that from deploying
VMs and infrastructure to the network side of things, so being flexible to go anywhere
and put things anywhere we can, that's kind of what we want to be doing.
Likewise from a management perspective as kind of a lead, tracking infrastructure in
terms of costing, project assignment, and life cycles when you're using multiple platforms
again is a pain, and as a small team, there's only two to four of us really focusing on
red teaming, so the more we can optimize our features and our functionality and make things
as streamlined as possible, the better, and if I can keep an eye on the bottom line, costing
where things are, great.
So those are the kind of what I identified as the challenges, and with that in mind,
I started, this is like the fifth time everyone's seen this meme, I think, today, or like yesterday,
but I started to kind of identify things that my platform must have to try and address those
kind of issues.
So easy to manage, so that's why I ended up going kind of the web route, I wanted to move
away from CLI and config files and constantly having to change and add things.
We used other platforms, like we used OST, and that kind of single pain, single area
you go to and just clicking, navigating, generating what you need to was perfect.
Secure, obviously with CI, CD, and Terraform, Ansible, you're storing a lot of secrets,
you're accessing data, so trying to design a platform in the most secure way possible,
probably not me best at, not being a full web dev, but I tried to take best steps to
minimize disclosure of secrets, only using them during runtime, encrypted storage, et
cetera.
Also making use of modern infrastructure approaches, there's not been a massive change in terms
of deploying Red Team infrastructure since the blue screen of Jeff days.
So doing this has been interesting, and we've touched on some of the key technologies I
look to use, Ansible, Terraform, and Tailscale, so Tailscale I'm probably going to bang on
about a lot today, but it's really been kind of a unifying technology to allow us to do
what we need to.
It must support at least Azure and AWS, so from our point of view, AWS is our core provider,
most of our infrastructure goes in there, Azure is a secondary, and that's kind of how
it's got to work as a minimum.
API driven as well, so everything within the web portal needs to be API driven, I want
to be able to slot it in anywhere and have projects spun up and designed by your upstream
sales pipelines to automatically generate and spin up resources, so API is a key.
And a modular design that even someone like me can quickly add new functionality to, you
don't need to be an absolute expert in Terraform, Ansible, you can just plop in new features,
new functions, new playbooks, and it will just work.
And also, like I said, which is kind of the end goal, is to start unifying as many data
sources from an engagement into a single area, so as an operator, as a lead, you can see
everything that's going on across your organization, across your teams, across the multiple jobs
you've got going on, and even now starting to ingest things like C2 logs, parsing, and
eventually look to introduce AI or learning models into further kind of digging into that
data and providing insight.
So as I mentioned, the kind of core technologies I'm looking at, tail scale is really the beating
heart of everything, it makes things so easy to tie everything together, and that's what's
really changed probably over the last couple of years with using that over previous Red
Team deployments, you know, you can have multiple resources in different providers, unify all
over a secure backend network, and communication is easy, there's no port forwarding, there's
no on-demand SSH tunnels spun up, public ports being available, there's no excuse for that
kind of stuff these days, you can just do it all over tail scale.
Django was something I kind of got to know a bit with tools like Ghostwriter, which you'll
probably see when you see the platform, where I've taken some of the inspiration and kind
of like the project-driven approach, and that I use as kind of a basis.
The one thing I hated about Django was its API framework, but Ninja API has come along
recently and it's basically fast API, but for Django it integrates with all of that,
and even for a mug like me, it's quite easy.
Mailgun as well, we use that for all of our mail notifications, the platform hooks into
things like Teams, Slack, Discord, to kind of keep operators up to date as things move
through different stages.
CloudFront, again, we use for automatic site generation and things like domain aging and
like aging them out, making things look legitimate.
Adobe OS, again, as I mentioned, our core provider, Azure, Ansible, and Terraform.
So everyone's probably familiar with a lot of those things, and I haven't done too much
of reinventing the wheel in terms of use of Terraform and Ansible, I've just kind of tarted
it up and made it look pretty.
So the core design concept, as I mentioned, hasn't really changed.
We're looking at deploying kind of private VPC groups per project, each group is individual
and self-contained, so for example, the internet-facing security groups and the private security groups
can't talk to each other over AWS, all traffic goes over the backend tail network, and this
lockdown of communication is just really, really useful.
So we can do exactly the same and have all of these resources within Azure, within GCP
or anywhere, and the network layout and architecture still stays exactly the same, it doesn't matter
where they're placed.
The overlaying architecture and control, again, which I'll talk about further on, around tail
net ACLs, again, gives us lots of control, so where the resources can't directly talk
to each other within the cloud platform, we can have them locked down.
So for example, project VPC1 and project VPC2 can't talk to each other at all in either
of the resources within Azure.
They also can't talk between projects over tail scale, but as an operator, you can come
in and talk to all projects and to your core networks, and your core networks can talk
to everywhere.
So with ACL taggings within tail scale, we can create really dynamic networks across
all different resources, easy peasy, it's no problem, doesn't matter, and the API for
things like tail scale and management, again, easy to plug into, add to the platform, we
can just deploy resources, tag it on the fly, and it's ready to go.
So yeah, tried and tested, probably not unfamiliar with the kind of basic layout of how the Red
Team sort of infrastructure looks.
The bonus as well with approach is we can add as many resources to a project as we want,
so anything from a simple penetration test or phishing assessment, you can have a single
go fish server deployed, for example, or you can have 30 C2 servers, it's entirely
up to you.
As I mentioned, we use kind of tail scale access controls, so we have operator devices,
core network devices, and then project systems, so project systems are dynamically created
every time you add a new project and prepare a resource, and then operator devices are
automatically joined when someone or a new person joins the tail scale network and adds
their own device to it.
Operator devices can access all areas of the network but cannot talk to each other
to prevent people from playing around with each other's devices.
Project devices cannot talk to other project devices but can talk to each other, so it's
easy to share things like back end network traffic over things like Red Elk and all other
services, C2 servers, for example.
The other thing we use is ephemeral keying or ephemeral tagging within tail scale, so
once a node goes down for a period of time, I think it's like half an hour, half an hour
to an hour, depending how often it refreshes, it used to be much slower, now it's much quicker,
the nodes are automatically removed, so we don't need to add in any other extra logic
to remove these from the tail net, once they're powered down and removed, they're gone, so
these kind of fundamental technologies within tail scale have made things considerably easier.
There's also additional features which I haven't really touched on, such as, you know, tail
scale provides the ability to SSH directly into hostess using tail scale.
We can also use back end certificate generation, so it uses Let's Encrypt, for example, on
the back end to generate accepted certificates within a private network, so we never have
to expose DNS records or anything else, we can just create private back end Let's Encrypt
certificates for things like Red Elk and it all just works, we get secure back end comms
all within our controlled network.
There are open source alternatives for the keying server and authentication server for
tail scale, so if you're in controlled environments and you have to have control of your own network
access and things like that and don't want to rely on tail scale as a company to do it,
you can do it in an open source way, you just have to host your own server.
So something to bear in mind.
And as for the actual platform itself, as I mentioned, it's a posh way of doing stupid
things quickly, so it basically does lots of moving around of templates.
So as long as you put things in the right area, you follow the correct naming conventions,
the portal will pick up what you're doing and move things into the correct area.
So if you go through an initial request for new infrastructure here, you'll submit a build
request to the API, which is pushed through from the front end, so it will automatically
pull things through like your project ID and project information and any other fields you
need to pass between the database.
It's one of the reasons I chose Django, because the relationship database set up on it is
so easy.
Again, I can do it, so it can't be that difficult.
The statuses as well are also tagged along on the back end to send updates and notifications
and also to limit certain features and functions kicking in at different times.
DNS records and DNS zone management is also included in the platform.
At the moment it only supports route 53, but it gives you the complete ability to track
domains and also assign them to resources as you build them on the fly.
So once that's done, effectively it takes all that information, including the modules,
so say for example we're building a team server, it will fire it through, build a unique project
location where it's going to hold all of that Terraform information, populate those templates
with the required bits of information.
The bonus of this is you can use templates and variables and areas that Terraform doesn't
usually let you use, so because we use Ginger on the back end just to move those templates
around and render them with the database information, we can set variables, name things
quickly and easily without having to rely on Terraform variables.
So we can name things differently, get away with a bit more than Terraform natively with
this allow.
Also one of the things I designed in through the whole process is often I'll screw something
up or I want to join or jump into a particular stage in the process and do something manually,
be it a quick change to a template or how I want to deploy something.
A lot of designs I see are so streamlined and only work in one way.
This again takes very much things in the old classic way, it will create sort of written
inventory files for things like Ansible, all the configurations for Terraform, the state
files are separated and isolated, so you can just jump into the back end Docker container,
change what you need to and rerun it and it will work.
So once it goes through the Terraform kind of apply status, all the directives are being
created, it will then start querying tail scale API and what it will do here is then
create the tagged project groups I mentioned with the ACLs, set up the rules for that based
on its templates and then it will also sit there and just wait for this information to
come back and then populate the private tail scale IP addresses into the database so now
you know and the portal knows where all your resources are and generate your Ansible inventory
files.
So now you've got all your on disk information, you've got your Ansible file to inventory
files all built, your infrastructure stood up, you now go through the final stage which
will be the Ansible configuration and again this just takes a playbook, you can have as
many playbooks for team servers as you want so you can keep up with all the latest hotness
and have all the best C2s with all your playbooks, no problem.
It also supports just raw variable input through the form so Ansible runner will just allow
you to input whatever amount of variables you want in a kind of key and value pair.
So if you are using your own playbooks and you want to import them, you can update the
front end forms to take in whatever variables you want, pass it down to Ansible runner,
your playbooks will have access to them and it's good to go and again that's all stored
in the database so you don't need to redo it, it's just there.
The playbook will then run, configure device and at that stage you have a complete project.
So we'll have a look at how that actually looks in practice when we get going.
As I mentioned adding new modules and new features is pretty straightforward, Ansible
updates, you follow module name, for example, team servers, assets will be files, things
that need to be moved around by your playbooks to be made available and you just put in as
many playbooks as you want, easy as that, you want to add a new playbook, just put it
in the folder.
Same goes for new modules within Terraform as well, you just add in new modules, ensure
you update a module load template from the template that's already available to you and
again you'll have new modules.
There are custom logic around certain things like there's malware, malleable profile passing
and things like that that happen depending on what module types you're using.
So there's like specialist modules with its own logic, but if you want to just add your
own raw module you can.
Again try to keep it really simple, just put files in the right places, name them right
you're good to go.
Demo time.
So yeah, so we'll have a quick look at the project.
So it's all as I mentioned like kind of web generated, so everything's dynamically added
and everything stems from projects.
I don't know why I'm looking up there, I've got it right in front of my face.
So once a new project's created you can see there's a number of different kind of pieces
of information we go through.
Again this can all be driven by the API so there's no need to manually go in and create
projects.
So for example we use pipe drive, so our upstream process would be a job's confirmed, it's booked,
that automatically raises a project, you can assign it to a lead, they get an email, you
go and you build your infrastructure.
We have separate areas like project IOCs and op logs which we'll have a look at when we
get a build going, end dates, notes, like full WYSIWYG support pretty much throughout.
As I mentioned like projects are the key, everything stems off a project, it's pretty
much assigned to that.
We can also have things like tasks, but again we'll circle back around as we get time.
The infrastructure is kind of the primary area we'll pay attention to today.
So you can see there's already a project deployed here which has a number of resources, so this
has like stage one, it's got an engine XHTPS redirector which is linked to that stage
one, we've also got a go fish server and a phishing redirect server, so you can name
the type name to put whatever you want, to give it custom names so you know what's going
on, platforms and its status and everything as I say it's tracked through.
You can see domain names are also excited, attached and picked up along with tail scale
private IPs, public IPs, et cetera, and there's also build terminals which is probably horrendously
formatted because Terraform loves to add colors and I haven't filtered it all out.
You can see all the back end stuff as it's going through, so adding the keys, builds,
you also get, if we keep scrolling, over the million builds I've done over the last few
days making sure nothing breaks.
You can also see things like the Ansible outputs as well for the playbooks as they go through,
so that's available again in the portal without having to go and find it yourself or get onto
the actual resources.
But what we'll do is we'll just quickly build something on the demo project, we'll just
build something nice and easy, so we'll go for a Nginx server, we'll build it on, in
fact actually we'll just add another domain, I purchased yesterday, if this works, like
my hands, my heart is fully in the hands of the demo god, so there you go, again this
dynamically pulls everything from route 53, so now DMX33F has been added, so we can go
back to infrastructure, add a new build, select the project, again we'll go for Nginx, we'll
select the DNS domain we want to use and we'll call this one reader.dmx33f.com and we'll
just call this one demo reader.
So that's now queued, effectively the database has been populated, that's ready to go.
What we'll now add for that as well, why not, we'll go for, nope, go for a phishing server,
again we'll go on that, we'll call it mail.dmx33f.com and we'll just call this go phish.
And again, that's now ready to go, so now we can just click prepare and as I mentioned
like during the process that's going to initialize Terraform, initialize all the directories,
build everything and then we can just work through the build steps as we go.
So the first initialization takes a little bit of time because it has to load the Terraform
provider and do all that kind of good stuff, but after that it's a fairly straightforward
process.
Again, we don't have to config Ansible at this point, we can do it later, we can do
it at the beginning, but we'll do that in a sec, shouldn't take too long, he says, hopefully
Everyone's staring at a spinning thing.
There we go.
So that's now updated to planned and what we'll do now is go and configure these, so
we'll start with go phish and we'll just do a clean go phish redirector, so again this
is going to, it's going to be any playbook you want, you can customize them however you
want, so this one for example is just going to spin up go phish, going to strip most of
the indicators via its docker deployment and then also with the redirector playbook it's
going to lock down sort of 443 and internet ports, so it only goes through the redirector.
So with that set, you can now see that's updated to configured and we'll configure the redirector
and again you get linked resources, so it says redirector C2, these can be the phishing
servers or C2s and it will automatically populate the backend NGINX configurations to make sure
the right ports go to the right tail scale server IPs and you're kind of good to go.
So we'll do a redirector on here, so we'll go for gscott.com, so basically covert redirect
URL, so anything that doesn't match any of the rules within our NGINX config is going
to be automatically redirected and we'll hit build on that.
So that will build everything in that project group and while that builds, because that
will take a little bit of time, we'll go have a look around some of the other kind of project
areas and one of the things I said I wanted to do was kind of unify as much information,
so things like managing DNS records can be fully done within the portal, so we can do
automatic mail gun registration, so click a button, you're automatically registered
with a mail gun, everything's done, everything's set up and the domain's added, you can then
just go add your SMTP user, you're good to go, phishing, everything else like that.
We can add custom records directly, we can do reputation checks, so you can see this
hooks into virus total, these can be run as part of a cron job or independently, so this
is probably quite similar to anyone who uses Ghostwriter, they have a DNS or a domain name
kind of register and management platform and that's where I kind of got the inspiration
from that.
This again is also showing that Terraform's running, there's a single backend queue at
the moment until I got it working, so if you're running a job and a Terraform job's running,
all other jobs that rely on Terraform, check that queue, so we can't do something like
an incubation domain at the moment, but what we have here usually which will click which
I'll come back to, we can deploy a domain based on categories either finance, health
or technology and it will deploy effectively a dummy website, dummy domain that you can
leave up to age and make your domain look legitimate for like a period of time, which
is pretty handy.
Recent features as well we've added is project IOCs as well, so again this is all API driven,
so we have ingesters that we can fire files into or points at file paths, it will go through
and add all the file hashes for the files you want to put in there, we can also go through
and add manual project IOCs, things like registry keys, service names, user agents, stuff like
that that we can then export and put into our reporting.
Op logs are pretty new, I think I finished it this week, I think it's still in my features
to do but I did it, so for example this is working at the moment with stage one and Cobalt,
so it will automatically parse logs as they're created and fire them to the API so we can
see when a new beacon comes in, we can also see when certain commands are run, we get
the output for them and then they're also automatically categorized based on their TTP
and what the command is that's run based on the database and that's populated, we can
export that directly into our reporting platform or provide it to the blue team so they can
see our full timeline of activity of what we're doing.
So yeah, that's like I said, that's one of my key ideas, when I say unified red team
automation, it really is to go back to like five year ago vibe of like single pane of
glass I guess would be the cliche term of bringing as much information together so you
can make like good decisions as an operator, good decisions as a lead and see what's going
on across your entire team.
So let's check back in and see how this is running, so the job is finished, you can see
the tail scale IPs have been updated, there's public IPs for both resources as by default
the mail templates automatically set up a public IP, but now the final step would just
be to run playbooks, so again we'll hit run maybe, I just can't click, if in doubt, so
configured, configured, built, yep, now click is not working, demo gods, come on, why you
do this to me, quick jump over, cannot process male profile, it's because there is no male
profile, it's probably why, fat fingers, never mind, phishing reader copy, so there we go,
so if you have a malleable profile playbook and it detects that you're using a malleable
profile and there's a stage one or a Cobalt strike malleable profile attached, it will
effectively pass it for you and populate that into the nginx config, so you have everything
ready to go for you and it should all be set up, so in theory now, that still doesn't run,
oh it does, there we go, so run playbook will now run, it will go through and do that, so
you can see again on the back end if you have a look, like it will set up the nginx phishing
server, redirects, all of that stuff, so we can check in on how that's going, but it seems
to be ticking along quite happily.
One other thing we've added recently and again is part of ongoing features, threat groups,
emulation plans and op vaults, so threat groups for example, we can import direct sticks
information, pass it and have groups, so we can edit TTPs, threat profiles and eventually
the plan is to have built emulation plans that we can import directly into vector for
purple teaming, but that's still kind of in progress, another idea which again, I have
to give a bit of credit to the Outflank guys for this, we kind of got inspiration from
using OST, so they have a way of sharing approaches and recipes effectively within their platform,
for different users, so one thing we've now included is a kind of an op vault, so this
allows us to pass various tools, import their Yara rules which will then eventually be applied
to CICD pipelines as tools are built, we can also pull out their detection rules, so this
for example is using Elastic, so it's their publicly available rules, and we can add kind
of bypass guidance, so if we've seen certain rules or certain detections during engagements,
perhaps as an operator come in for the next person to say look, if you're operating against
Elastic, consider taking this particular steps to avoid this, we've seen this being a detection,
use X, Y and Z repo, blah, blah, blah, also things like operational considerations can
be added as well, so if you're operating against Elastic EDR, don't use run DLL, use unicorn.dll
et cetera, so this is something we're hoping to kind of build out over time, as we engage
more and more kind of, as we do more and more engagements, we learn more and more about
different EDRs and we have somewhere to store that information, so yeah, that's something
quite cool that we added recently, we'll see if this playbook is still running, it still
is of course, so GoFish is still installing, it's installing Go, which will probably take
forever, but we can have a look at some of the other ones, so you can see kind of tail
scale IPs here for example for stage one, so if you go look at 107.4, I should show
the API, so Ninja API for those who haven't used it is quite interesting, it has all the
features, like I said, a fast API, so you get automatic API documentation, so everything
is generated as you go through, you don't need to mess around with any of that, and
like I said, I've tried to kind of keep everything API driven as much as possible, and this just
allows us to use it in as many different ways as possible, things like the op log and like
Yara parsers and Yara importers are much easier when you have an API to work with, so I didn't
think actually I'd be stood around waiting in all my demos, but there we go.
One of the other things we can quickly do, I should just show you this, if it works,
so again this is a brand new domain, you can see that these new records have been added,
we should also be able to just hit mailgun, and hope nothing goes wrong on the back end,
and this will now go off to query mailgun, we hit refresh again, and we see that all
of those MX records, all of the NS records, the CNAMEs, everything have been added, so
like I said, this domain is now fully configured to be used with mailgun.
The other things we can do is also assign domain names to certain projects, so we know
when a domain name is in use, add notes for things to ensure other teams aren't using
it for phishing, if it's reserved for red teaming or something else, but that's pretty
much how we designed it, so it can be used by any member of the team, you can be a seasoned
red teamer and jump in and deploy your infrastructure or just need to do a quick phishing assessment.
Why does this take so long?
Building Go Fish from Source.
What a time.
Stand around.
Everyone spends all their life just staring at spinny wheels.
But we'll show you one of the other redirectors as well, so if we have a look at stage one,
again, once an operator's joined to their network, we can quickly jump into any of the
back end stage ones, if that API, if that IP is even correct.
So you can see this dives now directly into our stage one instance, and again, this is
all private, it's all self-contained, there's no public ports exposed, there's no need to
risk anyone else being able to get access to our C2 infrastructure, even the AWS instances
themselves can't talk to each other, it all only happens over tail scale.
So, there we go.
IP table is ticking through now.
Update config files.
This is the slowest Playbook deploy I've ever done.
And then we start Go Fish again now, so this should be the final task, he says.
And what we also do here at the last stage is to cap the login credentials, so they're
available for certain things within the actual portal themselves, so now that job's been
completed.
If you need to then sign into the Go Fish instance, for example, that we've got, we
can scroll down through here.
Hit refresh.
Scroll down through here.
And we can go find the password and username.
So, you can just literally grab out the admin password.
We'll go grab the IP as well.
Go Fish.
So, now this has all been built on the fly here now.
So, we're going to go ahead and do that.
So, we're going to go ahead and do that.
Hit refresh.
So, now this has all been built on the fly here now.
Yes.
So, you can see in terms of deployments, in preparation for things like our assumed
breach assessments, our deployment times have gone from having to mess around for a day
